MultivDists 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Marginal Zero Inflated Bivariate Poisson Distribution - Laksh

Source: R/marZIBP_Laksh.R
marZIBP_Laksh.Rd

This function fit a marginal Zero Inflated Bivariate Poisson distribution under the of Lakshminarayana et. al (1993).

marZIBP_Laksh(mu1.fo, mu2.fo, psi.fo, data, initial.values = NULL)

Arguments

mu1.fo

a formula object to explain the marginal mean \(\mu_1\), the first response \(X_1\) on the left of an ~ operator, and the terms, separated by operators, on the right.

mu2.fo

a formula object to explain the marginal mean \(\mu_2\), the second response \(X_2\) on the left of an ~ operator, and the terms, separated by operators, on the right.

psi.fo

a formula object to explain the \(\psi\) parameter. An example could be: ~ age + salary.

data

a data frame containing the variables occurring in the formula2.

initial.values

a vector with possible initial values for the parameters.

Value

Returns a object with class marZIBP_Laksh.

References

Lakshminarayana, J., Pandit, S. N., & Srinivasa Rao, K. (1999). On a bivariate Poisson distribution. Communications in Statistics-Theory and Methods, 28(2), 267-276.

Author

Freddy Hernandez-Barajas, fhernanb@unal.edu.co

Examples

# Example 1 ---------------------------------------------------------------
l1 <- 3
l2 <- 4
alpha <- -0.90
psi <- 0.2

data1 <- rZIBP_Laksh(n=5000, l1=l1, l2=l2, alpha=alpha, psi=psi)
data1 <- as.data.frame(data1)

# To fit the model
mod1 <- NULL
mod1 <- marZIBP_Laksh(mu1.fo=X1~1,
                      mu2.fo=X2~1,
                      psi.fo=~1,
                      data=data1)
#> N = 4, M = 5 machine precision = 2.22045e-16

# To explore the estimations of l1, l2, mu and p

# To obtain E(Y1)=v1 and E(Y2)=v2
mod1$fitted.mu1[1]
#> [1] 2.434662
mod1$fitted.mu2[1]
#> [1] 3.195032

# To compare sample means with v1 and v2
colMeans(data1)
#>     X1     X2 
#> 2.4340 3.1948 

# To obtain alpha and psi
mod1$fitted.alpha
#> [1] -1.277685
mod1$fitted.psi[1]
#> [1] 0.1948003

# To obtain l1 and l2
mod1$fitted.l1[1]
#> [1] 3.023675
mod1$fitted.l2[1]
#> [1] 3.967999

# Example 2 ---------------------------------------------------------------

gen_data_ZIBP_Laksh <- function(n=10) {
  # To generate the covariates
  x1 <- runif(n=n)
  x2 <- runif(n=n)

  # To generate the means
  mu1 <- exp(-2 + 3.5 * x1 + 2.7 * x2)
  mu2 <- exp(-1 + 1.3 * x1 + 2.1 * x2)

  # To generate the p
  logit_inv <- function(x) exp(x) / (1+exp(x))
  psi  <- logit_inv(-2.4 + 1.2 * x2)

  alpha <- -1

  # To obtain lambdas
  l1 <- mu1 / (1-psi)
  l2 <- mu2 / (1-psi)

  # To generate Y1 and Y2
  y <- NULL
  for (i in 1:n)
    y <- rbind(y, rZIBP_Laksh(n=1, l1=l1[i], l2=l2[i],
                              alpha=alpha, psi=psi[i]))

  # To create the dataset
  dataset <- data.frame(y1=y[,1], y2=y[,2],
                        x1=x1, x2=x2,
                        mu1=mu1, mu2=mu2,
                        alpha=alpha, psi=psi,
                        l1=l1, l2=l2)

  return(dataset)
}

data2 <- gen_data_ZIBP_Laksh(n=100)
head(data2, n=8)
#>   y1 y2        x1         x2        mu1       mu2 alpha        psi         l1

mod2 <- NULL
mod2 <- marZIBP_Laksh(mu1.fo=y1~x1+x2,
                      mu2.fo=y2~x1+x2,
                      psi.fo=~x1+x2,
                      data=data2)
